document_title: What is a vasomotor headache? Symptoms, causes and treatments
subsection_content:
Symptoms of migraine
Migraines are the most common sign of vasomotor headaches; especially occurs in women and young people. Some rarer cases may occur in children. The disease can be episodic or chronic.
According to health experts, this can be a primary or secondary headache. Migraines can last from a few hours to a few days. When suffering from migraine, patients often have symptoms such as throbbing pain on one side of the head, nausea, dizziness, vision effects, loss of appetite, or restlessness and anxiety, etc.
Hormone disorders, insomnia, weather changes, side effects of some medications, caffeine or alcoholic beverage abuse, etc. are high risk factors for migraines. (2)
Symptoms of cluster headaches
Cluster headaches are a primary type of headache caused by neurovascular effects and are not a common form of vasomotor headache. Men from 20-40 years old are common subjects. Cluster headaches often occur in the head area above the eyes or in the temples; Usually takes about 30 minutes to 2 hours.
In addition to blood vessel dilation, some other causes related to cluster headache symptoms of vasomotor headache may be the activity of the immune system, circadian rhythm, autonomic nervous system,...
The pain caused by cluster headaches can appear at any time of the day, even in the middle of the night, causing the patient to feel intense burning pain. Other symptoms of headaches include: forehead sweating, watery eyes, swollen/droopy eyelids, stuffy nose, etc.
Cluster headaches often occur in the temples or the area above the eyes
Headache due to illness
There are many diseases that can cause patients to have symptoms of vasomotor headaches, such as flu, colds, high blood pressure, insomnia, etc. Depending on the different disease conditions, they will cause different levels of headaches. . In most cases, after treating the initial condition, the headaches will also be resolved.
